## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
Hi there, I have a few questions about using Verus. I was thinking of creating an ID with an i-address as its name. Is that a good idea?

**AI Assistant:**
Actually, I would advise against that. Creating an ID with an i-address as its name can cause problems when trying to use that ID or name in various cases, such as when referring to a currency. This is because an i-address will be interpreted as referring to a currency or identity that has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. It is not recommended to create an ID with an i-address as its name, as it may lead to user confusion. Is there anything else I can help you with?

**User:**
Okay, thanks for the warning. I was also thinking of creating a PBaaS chain with a name that is already used by a supported currency in Verus Desktop. Is that possible?

**AI Assistant:**
Unfortunately, in the current version of Verus Desktop, you cannot create a PBaaS chain with a name that is already used by a supported currency, such as BTC or ETH. However, this limitation is expected to be resolved in future releases. It's always a good idea to check the documentation and updates for the latest information on what's possible with Verus.

**User:**
One more thing, I've been using the experimental and unfinished software of Verus. Are there any specific things I should be aware of when using it?

**AI Assistant:**
Yes, it's very important to be aware that the software is experimental and unfinished, and use it at your own risk. There is no warranty for any kind of damage that may occur. It is recommended to use caution and follow best practices when using the software. Make sure to back up your data and be prepared for potential errors or issues. We're working hard to improve and stabilize the software, but for now, please be cautious when using it.
What is a potential issue with creating an ID with an i-address as its name in Verus?

Creating an ID with an i-address as its name can cause problems when trying to use that ID or name in various cases, such as when referring to a currency. This is because an i-address will be interpreted as referring to a currency or identity that has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. It is not recommended to create an ID with an i-address as its name, as it may lead to user confusion.

### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of:
1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.# DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage!
